1.c: Poor repair condition of properties, Distance to negro schools. Lack of paved streets.
1.b: Close to occupants' source of employment. Street car transportation along Peachtree Road.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Buckhead negro area (outside city)

1.c: Proximity of Atlanta and West Point R.R. to southern portion of area and of negro property to eastern boundary.
1.b: Zoned for residential and restricted. Street car transportation on Stewart Avenue. Proximity to schools, churches, and community business centers.
1.a: Level to slightly sloping wooded land.

2.a: Business and professional men, some clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area, should be held for fair value.

6.1: Capitol View Manor

C38.name: End of Howell Mill car line section

1.c: Proximity to D grade white property and Seaboard Shops. Heavy vehicular traffic along Howell Mill Road and Collier Road.
1.b: Street car transportation along Howell Mill road to edge of area

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold, rather than held. Only about 20 houses in the area.

6.1: End of Howell Mill car line section

A9.name: Glennwood Estates (in DeKalb County and City of Decatur)

1.c: Practically non except western portion of area adjoins Decatur Cemetery.
1.b: Restricted and zoned for residential. Proximity to schools, churches, Agnes Scott College (girls), street car transportation, negro area D-3 for servants.
1.a: Rolling, wooded land, with natural home sites.

areaDesc.5: This is new extension of subdivision which was developed about 10 years ago (B-19), hence contains only new construction. Practically all of the houses have been erected during past 2 years. Property, if acquired in this area, should be held for fair value.

6.1: Glenwood Estates (in Dekalb County and City of Decatur)

D8.name: Poorest portion of Oakhurst (in Decatur, DeKalb County)

1.c: Age and repair condition of properties. Difficulty of rental conditions. About 50% of streets unpaved.
1.b: Proximity to schools and community business centers. Street car transportation on Howard Avenue and Oakview Road.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Poorest portion of Oakhurst (in Decatur, DeKalb County)

D31.name: Two negro sections of College Park

1.c: Only northewast and extreme southwest portions accessible to trackless trolley line on Main Street. Proximity to College Park Cemetery, Municipal Airport and College Park business area. Difficulty of rental collections. Poor repair condition of many properties. Instability of incomes of occupants of area.
1.b: Proximity to occupants' source of employment and negro schools, churches, and community business centers in sub-area west of A&WPRR.

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold, rather than held. Extreme southwest portion located near Cox College is 100% negro, whereas remainder of area in eastern part of College Park is about 25% negro.

6.1: Two negro sections of College Park

1.c: Area traversed by main line of A & WPRR. About 6 to 7 miles from center of Atlanta. Heavy vehicular traffic along Main Street. Near Municipal Airport. Some unpaved streets. Repair condition of many properties.
1.b: Schools, churches, Cox College (girls), Georgia Military Academy, and community business centers in area. Trackless trolley along Main Street.

2.a: College Park business men, clerical and factory workers, and some skilled mechanics

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Older portion of College Park

1.c: only extreme northern portion served by trackless trolley transportation. Traversed by main line of A&WPRR and important highway. Heavy vehicular traffic. Poor repair condition of many properties. Mixture of racial groups. Considerable distance from Atlanta business center.
1.b: Proximity to occupants' source of employment.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Southern portion of College Park

B27.name: Best residential area of College Park

1.c: Considerable distance from Atlanta business center. Atlanta Municipal Airport located about 2 miles from area.
1.b: Restricted. Reasonably accessible to schools (Georgia Military Academy), churches, and community business centers. Trackless trolley transportation along Main street.

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Best residential portion of College Park

1.c: Proximity to industrial plants along Murphy Avenue and Sylvan Road and proximity of northern portion to belt line of A and WPRR. Heavy vehicular traffic along Sylvan Road/Dill and Stewart Avenue

2.a: Mostly clerical workers, some factory workers

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold, rather than held

6.1: Capitol View

1.c: Heavy vehicular traffic along Church and Main Streets. Some unpaved streets. Proximity to industrial property and main line of Central of Georgia RR and A&WP. Property adjoins portion of D areas- D-26, 27, and 28. Considerable distance from center of city.
1.b: Schools, churches, community business centers in area. Trackless trolley transportation along Main Street. Close to occupants' sources of employment.

2.a: Clerical and factory workers; skilled mechanics

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Older portion of East Point

1.c: Encroachment of small business. Diffulty of rental collections. Instability of incomes of area's occupants. Considerable distance to negro schools. Poor repair condition of properties.
1.b: Proximity to occupants' source and East Point business center.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held. This is known as the best negro section of East Point.

6.1: Negro area of East Point

D26.name: Area surrounding Southern Wood Preserving Company's plant (East Point)

1.c: Proximity to Southern Wood Preserving plant and industrial area of East Point. Heavy vehicular traffic along Main Street and Chattahoochee Avenue. Poor repair condition of properties.
1.b: Proximity to occupants' source of employment. Street car transportation along Main Street.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Area surrounding Southern Wood Preserving Company's plant (East Point)

1.c: Proximity to fertilizer and Southern Wood Preserving plants, Fort PcPherson, and railroad yards. Heavy vehicular traffic along Lee Street. Area bisected by main lines of Central of Georgia and A & W P railroads and belt line of L & N RR

2.a: Railroad men, factory workers and some clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Colonial Hills, East Point

1.c: Distance to Atlanta business center. Proximity to industrial plants.
1.b: Restricted. Proximity to schools, churches, community business centers, and occupants' sources of employment. Trackless trolley transporation along Main Street.

areaDesc.5: Extension of Jefferson Park contains practically all of the present new residential construction in the area (this new construction is largely speculative). Southern and eastern portion of this area contain considerable volume of new construction and are entitled to A grade rating.

6.1: Jefferson Park, East Point

D29.name: Low grade white area in Hapeville, near Swift & Co's fertilizer plant

1.c: Proximity to fertilizer plants and main line of Central of Georgia RR. Southern portion of area considerable distance from schools, Difficulty of rental collections. Instability of incomes of area's occupants. Proximity to Municipal Airport. Lack of paved streets.
1.b: Proximity to occupants' source of employment. Street car transportation along Central Avenue.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Low grade white area in Hapeville, near Swift & Co's fertilizer plant

1.c: Encroachment of tourist homes and business along Steward Avenue and west extremity of Virginia Avenue. Proximity to Municipal Airport. Heavy vehicular traffic along Virginia Avenue and Stewart Avenue. Proximity of orphans' home and of fertilizer plants to northwestern portion. Some unpaved streets. Spotted repair condition of many properties.
1.b: Schools, churches, community business centers in area. Street car line along Central Avenue.

2.a: Clerical and factory workers; skilled mechanics

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Newer portion of Hapeville

1.c: Considerable distance from center of Atlanta. Near Atlanta Municipal Airport. Inadequate transportation facilities. Distance to schools. Near orphans home.
1.b: Proximity to Hapeville business

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area, should be sold, rather than held. There is considerable cheap type construction in area.

6.1: Southern portion of Hapeville

1.c: Orphan's Home in area. Encroachment of business on Central Avenue (main highway). Proximity to lumber yards and industrial plants. Area traversed by main line of Central of Georgia RR. Mixture of racial groups. Poor repair condition of properties. Difficulty of rental collections. Proximity to Municipal Airport.
1.b: Proximity to Hapeville Business section, schools, churches, and playgrounds.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Oldest portion of Hapeville

1.c: Proximity to West View Cemetery.
1.b: Zoned for residential and restricted. Reasonably accessible to schools, churches, and community business centers. Street car transportation along Cascade Avenue.

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held.

6.1: West End Park

1.c: Northern portion affected adversely by West View Cemetery and city tuberculosis hospital, as well as proximity to negro property. Belt line of L and N R R traverses area. Heavy traffic along Gordon, Lucile and WestView Avenues.
1.b: Street car transportation along Lucile Avenue and Gordon Street. Schools, churches, park, and community business center in area. Restricted to residential.

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area, should be sold, rather than held. Considerable jerry-building took place along Olympian Way and Olympian Circle in southern portion.

6.1: Newer portion of West End

1.c: Proximity to L and N Railroad freight yards.
1.b: Proximity to West End Golf Club. Zoned for residential and restricted. Street car transportation along Cascade Avenue and Gordon Street. Reasonably accessible to schools, churches, and community business centers.

areaDesc.5: (a) Increased sale price is due to construction of more expensive type during past year. Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held.

6.1: S-W portion of West End

1.c: Advanced age and poor repair condition of many properties
1.b: Street car transportation along Lee and Gordon Street and business center in area. Two miles from center of city. Majority of restricted and zoned for residential

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold as quickly as possible. This is one of the oldest residential areas in Atlanta. Along Rose Circle is a group of 15 or 20 Br. Veneer bungalows about 10 years old which are better grade property than remainder of area.

6.1: Older portion of West End

D16.name: Lee Street section of West End

1.c: Heavy vehicular traffic along Lee Street. Age and dilapment of business and proximity to main line of A and WPRR and Central of Georgia. Encroachment of boarding houses.
1.b: Proximity to West End business section. Street  car transportation along Lee Street.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold as quickly as possible.

6.1: Lee Street section of West End

1.c: Proximity of northern portion at L & N R R freight yards and of eastern portion to main line of Central of Georgia and A and W P R R. Heavy vehicular traffic along Lee Street. Age and spotted repair condition of many properties. Some negro property, Cheap "shot-gun" type predominates.
1.b: School, park, churches, and community business centers in area. Trackless trolley along Lee Street.

2.a: Skilled mechanics and factory workers; some laborers

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold, rather than held. Some negro property located in Dimmock Street and Lee Alley.

6.1: Oakland City area

1.c: Proximity to industrial plants along A and WPRR. Poor repair condition of many properties. Location of negro property along Osborne Avenue in southern portion.
1.b: Reasonably accessible to school in B-23 and street carline along Lee street. Close to occupants' source of employment.

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold as quickly as possible.

6.1: Forrest Park

1.c: Proximity to industrial enterprises along Atlanta and West Point Railroad.
1.b: School in area. Proximity to community business centers. Zoned for residential. Bus transportation along Sylvan Road.

areaDesc.5: Property acquired in this area should be sold rather than held

6.1: Sylvan Hills

1.c: Poor repair condition of properties. Proximity to industrial plants and Southern RR. Heavy vehicular traffic on McDonough Blvd., Jonesboro Road and Pryor Street. Lack of paved streets and adequate sewage disposal facilities in extreme southwest portion. Difficulty of rental collections.
1.b: Negro schools, churches, and community business centers in area. Proximity to Clark University (negro); street car transportation along McDonough Road and Lakewood Avenues.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired should be sold, rather than held. This is considered fairly good negro area because of Clark University influence and is one of highest negro home ownership area in community.

6.1: Negro section near Clark University

C29.name: Lakewood Heights (southern portion of area outside city limits)

1.c: Heavy vehicular traffic along Lakewood Avenue and Jonesboro road. Cheap type of construction in portion of area. Proximity to Southern Railroad and encroachment of business. Adjoins negro area D-14
1.b: Street car transportation along Lakewood Avenue. Schools, churches, community business centers in area.

2.a: Clerical and factory workers; skilled mechanics

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Lakewood Heights

1.c: Poor repair condition of properties. Instatility of incomes of occupants of area. Lack of paved streets. Proximity to industrial plants, Federal Prison, and Southern Railroad. Difficulty of rental collections.
1.b: Street car line on Lakewood Avenue. Proximity to schools, churches, and community business centers.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Lower portion of Lakewood Heights

1.c: Proximity to Southern Railroad, Federal Prison, and D grade white property in D-13
1.b: Restricted to residential. Street car trasnportation on Lakewood Avenue. Proximity to schools, churches, and community business centers.

areaDesc.5: (a) All houses which have been completed are occupied; 5 now under construction. Only about 17 or 18 houses in this area. This is a new subdivision in which all homes are less than a year old and those currently being erected are being financed under 90% FHA loans. Sufficient undeveloped area is available to erect about 65 houses in this immediate community. This little area might almost be rated a B grade area as construction is of fairly substantial type. However, surrounding type of property influences economic suitability to site.

6.1: Oak Knolls

1.c: Proximity to Federal Prison, Chevrolet plant, and other industrial plants located along Southern Railroad, and belt line of A and W P Railroad. Some streets unpaved. Heavy traffic along Boulevard and McDonough Road.
1.b: Proximity to schools, community business centers, occupants' sources of employment. Street car transportation along McDonough Boulevard.

2.a: Clerical, factory workers, and skilled mechanics

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area, should be sold, rather than held. Presence of Federal Prison and Chevrolet Plant creates good rental demand for property in this area.

6.1: Federal Prison area

1.c: Poor repair condition of properties, difficulty of rental collections. some vandalism. Lack of paved streets. Proximity to lumber yards, industrial plants, and Southern RR Shops.
1.b: Street car transportation on McDaniel Street and Stewart Avenue. Negro schools, churches, and community business centers scattered throughout area. Proximity to many occupants' sources of employment (Southern RR Shops).

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold rather than held. This is known as a good negro rental area, particularly when railroad employment is high.

6.1: Pittsburgh

1.c: Adjoins negro area D-15. Heavy vehicular traffic along Stewart Avenue. West and north portion of area adjoins industrial plants and railroad lines.
1.b: Restricted to residential. Street car transportation along Stewart Avenue. Schools, park and community business cetners in area.

2.a: Clerical and factory workers; skilled mechanics

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Adair Park

D18.name: Bellwood to Atlanta University, east of Ashby Street and west of Marietta Street

1.e: Down for white, Static for negro
1.c: Age and poor repair condition of many properties. Difficulty of rental collections. Vandalism. Instability of incomes of occupants of area. Mixture of racial groups. Many unpaved streets. Entire area subject to smoke dirt and noises of network of railroads and industrial enterprises along eastern and northern boundaries. Heavy traffic along Bankhead Avenue and Simpson, Hunter and Greensferry Sts.
1.b: Proximity to center of city and occupants' sources of employment. Good street car transportation facilities. Schools (both negro and white) and community business centers scattered throughout area.

2.a: Mill workers, factory workers, laborers and domestics

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held. P.W.A. low-cost housing project, housing approximately 600 families, located near Spellman along Lumpkin and Mildred Streets in southern portion of area.

6.1: Bellwood to Atlanta University, east of Ashby Street and west of Marietta Street.

1.c: Heavy vehicular traffic along Ashby, Hunter, and Simpson Streets.
1.b: Negro schools, parks, Atlanta University (negro). community business centers and churches in area. Street car transportation to southern portion on Fair Street, south-central portion on Hunter Street, and along Ashby and Bankhead Avenue in northern portion. Majority of streets paved.

2.a: Negro business and professional men; clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area, should be held for fair value. This is known as best negro area in Atlanta and contains best type of negro residents and highest percentage of negro home ownership.

6.1: Best negro section in Atlanta

1.c: Heavy vehicular traffic along Bankhead Ave (Birmingham Highway). Heterogeneous types of improvements. Spotted repair condition of many properties. Encroachment of business along Bankhead Avenue.
1.b: Reasonably accessible to schools, Maddox Park and traversed by Bankhead street-carline.

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold, rather than held

6.1: Grove Park section (outside city)

1.c: Street car line serves only northern portion. Many streets unpaved. Proximity to city dump yards and railroad yards and industrial plants. Difficulty of rental collections.
1.b: Close to occupants' source of employment.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Rockdale Park (outside city)

1.c: Surrounded by industrial property and railroad yards.
1.b: Close to occupants' source of employment. Street car transportation on Marietta Street. Schools, Churches, and community business centers in area.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Howell Hill Station area

1.c: Proximity to Crestlawn Cemetery and to railroad yards, with smoke and dirt. About five miles from center of city. Difficulty of rental collections.
1.b: Close to occupants' source of employment. Marietta Street car line traverses area. Schools and community business centers in area.

2.a: Railroad workers and some clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Hills Park (outside city)

D25.name: Howell Mill car line and Seaboard R.R. Shops section (outside only)

1.c: Poor repair condition of some properties. Some streets unpaved. Difficulty of rental collections. Instability of occupants' incomes. Proximity to Seaboard shops and lines. Heavy vehicular traffic along Chattahoochee Avenue and Howell Mill Road.
1.b: Proximity to occupants' source of employment. Howell Mill street car line traverses area. Schools, churches, and communnity business centers in area.
1.a: Western portion, mostly level; eastern portion, sloping.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Howell Mill car line and Seaboard RR Shops section (outside city)

B8.name: Spring Lake Park and Collier Road section (outside city)

1.c: Considerable distance from fire station, schools, churches, and community business cetners. Heavy vehicular traffic along Northside Drive. Water rate twice city rate.
1.b: Restricted. Near municipal golf course. Low effective tax rate.

2.a: Business and professional men; some office workers

areaDesc.5: New construction is taking place in easter portion of area along Collier Road and in northern portion of Spring Lake Park section. Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Spring Lake Park and Collier Road section (outside city)

B9.name: A.J. Collier Estate Subdivision and Brookwood (northern portion outside city)

1.c: Presence of apartments in northern portion of area. Water rate twice that of city. Proximity to steel company and main line of Southern R.R. Considerable distance from fire station at Buckhead.
1.b: Restricted. Low effective tax rate in northern portion. Street car transportation along Peachtree Road.

2.a: Business and professional men; some office workers

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in southern portion of area, should be sold; if in northern portion, should be held for fair value.

6.1: A. J. Collier Estate Subdivision and Brookwood (northern portion outside city)

C4.name: Peachtree Road section between Brookwood and Seaboard RR (majority outside city)

1.c: Area is bounded on north by main line of Seaboard Railraod and on South by main line of Southern Railroad. Heavy vehicular traffic along Peachtree Road. Encroachment of apartments and commercial properties along with prospective Montgomery-Ward development in southern portion of area.
1.b: Street car transportation along Peachtree Road.

a.3: Gasoline stations, community business centers, etc.

areaDesc.5: This is principally an apartment house section, apartments in this area having a good rental demand, since most of the apartments are outside the city and the occupants escape city taxation. Wide variation of family income is due to the fact that some of the community's well-to-do citizens still live in original homes in area. Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Peachtree Road section between Brookwood and Seaboard RR (majority outside city)

1.c: In northern portion, water rate is twice that of city. Considerable distance from fire station at Buckhead. Proximity of main line of Southern R.R. to southern portion of area.
1.b: Well restricted. Low effective tax rate. Proximity to community business center. Recreational park and swimming pool in area. Street car transportation along Peachtree Road.

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in this area, should be held for fair value.

6.1: Brookwood Hills (Northern portion outside city)

D19.name: North Avenue to Cain Street, between Luckie and Spring Streets

1.c: Heavy vehicular traffic along Luckie St. and Techwood Drive. Low-grade white element occupying southern portion of area. Age and poor repair condition of properties. Mixture of racial groups. Difficulty of rental collections.
1.b: Proximity to center of city and occupants' sources of employment. Good bus transportation facilities. Proximity to PWA Techwood project, housing some 600 families; schools and several community business centers in area.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold as quickly as possible.

6.1: North Avenue to Cain Street, between Luckie and Spring Streets

D21.name: Fourteenth Street to North Avenue, between State St. and Marietta St.

1.c: Proximity to stockyards, main line of several railroads and industrial plants located on same. Some unpaved streets. Heavy vehicular traffic along Marietta Street and Hemphill Avenue. Age and poor repair condition of many properties. Instability of income of area's occupants.
1.b: Street car transportation on Marietta Street and Hemphill Avenue. Schools, churches, community business in area. Close to occupants' sources of employment.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold as quickly as possible.

6.1: Fourteenth Street to North Avenue, between State St. and Marietta St.

C7.name: Section between Sixth and Sixteenth Streets and State and Spring Sts

1.c: Inadequate transportation facilities to most of area. Proximity to steel company and industrial plants and to D grade white property. Slight infiltration of lower income groups. Spotted repair condition of properties.
1.b: Zoned for residential. Proximity to schools and to occupants' sources of employment.

2.a: Clerical workers, skilled mechanics and factory workers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Section between Sixth and Sixteenth Streets and State and Spring Sts

1.c: Proximity to D grade property to western portion of area.
1.b: Zoned for residential and restricted. Proximity to schools, including Georgia Tech, churches, and business center of city. Ample street car transortation. Proximity to Georgia Tech creates rental demand in this area.

2.a: College professors and instructors, some clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area, should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Peters Park

C6.name: Section north of Fourteenth Street between Piedmont Park and Spring Street to Brookwood Station

1.c: Encroachment of apartments, community business centers, and boarding houses. Heavy vehicular traffic along West Peachtree and Peachtree Streets and Piedmont Avenue.
1.b: Street car transportation along West Peachtree St, Peachtree Street, and Piedmont Avenue. Parks and recreational centers. Proximity to schools, churches, and community business centers. Reasonably accessible to center of city.

2.a: Mixture: Executives and business men, and some clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area, should be sold rather than held. Most of city's largest apartment houses are in this area which is desirable rental area because of transportation facilities and proximity to center of city.

6.1: Section north of Fourteenth Street between Piedmont Park and Spring Street to Brookwood Station

1.c: Age and fair repair condition of many properties in area. Presence of multiple family structures in area.
1.b: Proximity to center of city, community shopping centers, schools, churches, parks, playgrounds. Street car transportation on Peachtree and Piedmont, plus bus line through area. Restricted and zoned.

areaDesc.5: (a) Collier Woods- new subdivision (Beverly Road). (b) Ansley Park proper. This is the oldest still desirable residential area in city and although many og the properties are quite old, there is a good demand for property in the area- principally from rental standpoint. Future outlook for property in this area is slowly downward; hence, if property is acquired in this area, it should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Collier Woods and Ansley Park

B11.name: Ansley Park Annex and northern portion of Ansley Park

1.c: Considerable distance from schools. Belt line R.R. (seldom used) runs through area.
1.b: Near Ansley Park golf course. Restricted and zoned for residential. Parks and recreational centers. Bus transportation. Proximity to community business centers.

2.a: Business and professional men; clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in this area, should be held for fair value

6.1: Ansley Park Annex and northern portion of Ansley Park

D2.name: Negro area near Armour Fertilizer Plant (outside city)

1.c: Poor repair condition of properties. Proximity of fertilizer plants and main line of Southern R.R., Inadequate facilities for sewage disposal.
1.b: Close to occupants' source of employment

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held

6.1: Negro area near Armour Fertilizer Plant (outside city)

1.c: Spotted condition of properties, both as to age and repair. Heavy vehicular traffic along Piedmont Road and Chesire Bridge Road. Enchroachment of business properties. Lack of zoning and restrictions. Water rate twice that of city. Considerable distance from Buckhead fire station. Dependent upon Fulton County police protection. Proximity to commercial and industrial plants, including two fertilizer plants along main line of Seaboard
1.b: No important favorable influence other than area's proximity to schools.

2.a: Some business men and clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Mayfair (outside city)

C10.name: North Boulevard, between Amsterdam Avenue and Montgomery Ferry Road

1.c: Heavy vehicular traffic along Boulevard. Distance to schools and churches. Proximity to business property located along Southern Railroad belt line. Governor's Horse Guards located in northern portion of area.
1.b: Proximity to restricted residential area. Community business center, park, and recreation center. Bus transportation.

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held.

6.1: North Boulevard, between Amsterdam Avenue and Montgomery Ferry Road

1.c: Some streets unpaved. Heavy traffic along Hardee Street, Boulevard and Memorial Drives. Proximity to Pullman Company and fertilizer plants.
1.b: South Decatur carline traverses southern portion; northern portion served by line immediately north of railroad. Schools churches and community business center in area.

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold, rather than held. In north central portion of area, along Sisson Avenue, Leland Terrace and west side of Winter Avenue (which street is boundary between Atlanta and Decatur) there is a small subdivision which was developed in 1928-1929 and contains a better type house than is found elsewhere in the area. The houses in this small sub-area might almost be rated "low-grade blue."

6.1: Kirkwood (in DeKalb County)

B13.name: Morningside, Rock Springs Rd setion and better portions of North Boulevard Park, North Highlands and Virginia Highlands

1.c: None
1.b: Proximity to parks, playgrounds, community business centers and schools. Restricted and zoned for residential. Street car and bus transportation.

i.6: Built for owners; hence, no sales

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be held for fair value. This is large area which contains some spotted localities, but majority of area is entitled to B grade rating.

6.1: Morningside, Rock Springs Rd section and better portions of North Boulevard Park, North Highlands and Virginia Highlands

A8.name: Lenox Park, Johnson Estates, and Hyland Park (Lenox Park is in Fulton County, while Johnson Estates and Hyland Park are in DeKalb County; most of Hyland Park is outside city limits)

1.c: Water rate in most of Hyland Park is twice that of city rate. Influx of Jewish families in Johnson estates.
1.b: Restricted and zoned for residential. Construction in Lennox park must be approved by subdivision's architects. Bus transportation facilities. Proximity to city grade schools and reasonably accessible to community business centers and churches.
1.a: Rolling land in Lennox Park and majority of Johnson Estates, well wooded.

areaDesc.5: Practically all of the houses in this area have been erected since the depression. Property, if acquired in this area, should be held for fair value.

6.1: Lenox Park, Johnson Estates, and Hyland Park (Lennox Park is in Fulton County, while Johnson Estates and Hyland Park are in Dekalb County; most of Hyland park is outside city limits)

C12.name: Highland Avenue section from Ponce de Leon Avenue to University Drive

1.c: Heavy traffic along Highland Avenue. Encroachment of apartments in southern portion. Age of properties in southern portion.
1.b: Street car transportation on Highland Avenue. Proximity to schools, churches, and community business centers. Majority of northern portion (Highland Avenue excepted*) zoned and restricted to residential.

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Highland Avenue section from Ponce de Leon Avenue to University Drive.

C8.name: Section between Ponce de Leon Ave and Fourteenth St. and Spring Street and Southern RR Belt Line

1.c: Heavy traffic along Spring, West Peachtree, and Peachtree Streets and Piedmont Avenue, Parkway Drive, and Boulevard. Proximity to baseball park. Encroachment of apartments and boarding houses. Spotted repair condition and age of properties.
1.b: Proximity to parks, center of city, recreation centers, schools, churches, community business centers, bus and street car transportation. Majority zoned for residential (to include apartments), and considerable portion restricted exclusively to residential.

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held. (a) Wide spread of income due to fact that some of city's older business men still reside in original homes in the area. (b) Present sales prices based principally on purchase of homes for boarding houses on investment basis-not for home ownership. (c) Comparatively high rental prices pertain principally to northeast section because of proximity to schools.

6.1: Section between Ponce de Leon Ave and Fourteenth St. and Spring Street and Southern RR Belt Line

C9.name: Section between Ponce de Leon and Forrest Aves and Parkway Drive and Sou. R.R. Belt Line

1.c: Heavy vehicular traffic on Ponce de Leon and Forest Avenue, Parkway Drive and Boulevard. Notorious reputation of western portion of area. Adjoins negro and white D grade property. Presence of business and apartments in area.
1.b: Proximity to center of city, street car transportation on Ponce de Leon and Forrest Avenues and Boulevard. Schools and community business centers in area. Proximity of large Sears-Roebuck distributing plant for southeast to area creates strong rental demand for properties in eastern portion of area.

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold as quickly as possible. (a) Due to Sears-Roebuck rental effect in eastern portion of area.

6.1: Section between Ponce de Leon and Forrest Aves and Parkway Drive and Sou. R.R. Belt Line

D20.name: North Avenue to Edgewood Avenue, between Piedmont Avenue and Southern R.R. belt line

1.e: Down for white, Static for negroes.
1.c: Age and dilapidated condition of many properties. Difficulty of rental collections. High juvenile delinquency, infant mortality, tuberculosis incidence, death rate, and adult crime rate. Heavy vehicular traffic throughout area. Different racial groups
1.b: Proximity to center of city and occupants' sources of employment. Negro schools, churches and community business centers throughout area. Good street car transportation facilities.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold as quickly as possible. Although this area is considered a good negro rental area from an investment standpoint, it also contains one of the city's worst slum areas.

6.1: North Avenue to Edgewood Avenue, between Piedmont Avenue and Southern RR belt line

C14.name: Ponce de Leon Avenue to Edgewood Ave. between Moreland Ave. and Southern Railroad belt line (includes Linwood, Copenhill, and Inman Park)

1.c: Age of properties in southern portion of area. Proximity of white D grade property and industrial plants along Southern Railroad belt line. Tourist homes, boarding houses and apartments in northern portion of area.
1.b: Reasonably accessible to center of city. Street car transportation of Highland Avenue, Ponce de Leon, Edgewood Avenue, and Euclid, Schools, churches, and community business centers in area.

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold as quickly as possible.

6.1: Ponce de Leon Avenue to Edgewood Ave. between Moreland Ave. and Southern Railroad belt line (includes Linwood, Copenhill and Inman Park).

C13.name: Hancock subdivision, Atkins Park, western edge of Druid Hills, and University Park (portion of this area is in Fulton County and portion in DeKalb; portion also outside of city)

1.c: Restrictions in Atkins Park expire soon. Heavy vehicular traffic along Highland Avenue and Briar Cliff Road. Presence of apartments in area and proximity of northern portion of area to dairy and laundry. Spanish type of architecture in Hancock subdivision. Considerable distance from schools.
1.b: Street car transportation on Highland Avenue and Briar Cliff Rd. Proximity to churches and community business center. Portion of area outside city escapes city taxation, but is subject to DeKalb County taxation; this portion dependent upon DeKalb County police protection.

2.a: Executives and business men, some clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Hancock subdivision, Atkins Park, western edge of Druid Hills, and University Park (portion of this area is in Fulton County and portion in DeKalb; portion also outside of city).

1.c: Heavy vehicular traffic along DeKalb Avenue. Area bounded on north by main line of Georgia R R. Poor repair condition of properties. Difficulty of rental collections.
1.b: Street car transportation along Railraod. Proximity to community business center.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Poorest section of Kirkwood (DeKalb County)

C15.name: Little Five Points section east to East Lake Road

1.c: Heavy vehicular traffic along Moreland, McLendon, and DeKalb Avenue. Age of properties in western portion. Proximity of southern portion to main line of Georgia Railroad and fertilizer and industrial plants along same.
1.b: Proximity to park, recreation center, restricted residential area and community business centers. Schools in area. Street car transportation along Moreland Avenue, McLendon, and DeKalb Avenue.

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Little Five Points section east to East Lake Road

C21.name: Melrose and Drexel Avenue section (in DeKalb County and city of Decatur)

1.c: Proximity to negro area D-7 and main line of Georgia R.R.
1.b: Restricted to residential. Street car transportation along Howard Avenue. Reasonably accessible to schools and community business center.

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold as quickly as possible. This is cheapest and poorest grade white area in Decatur.

6.1: Melrose and Drexel Avenue section (in DeKalb County and city of Decatur)

B14.name: Druid Hills (Majority outside city - all of area in DeKalb County)

1.c: Considerable distance to schools for most of area occupants. Restrictions in oldest portion of this subdivision expire in 1940. Infiltration of Jewish families. Water rates outside city twice those inside city. Portion outside city dependent upon DeKalb Country police protection and special arrangement necessary for fire protection. Heavy vehicular traffic along Ponce de Leon Avenue
1.b: Near Druid Hills Golf Club and Emory University. Large lots well restricted, portion inside city zoned for residential, street car transportation.

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held. Due largely to the expiration of restrictions in 1940, plus present trend toward smaller homes, the future outlook for this area is slowly downward. Some of the community's finest homes and most substantial citizens reside in large expensive homes on both sides of Ponce de Leon Avenue; however, the site of these properties makes sale of same difficult.

6.1: Druid Hills (Majority outside city- all of area in DeKalb County)

C16.name: Emory University section and northeast portion of Druid Hills (outside city - in DeKalb County)

1.c: Open creek through western portion. Heavy traffic along North Decatur Road. Presence of hospital in area. Outside of city, hence dependent upon DeKalb County police protection.
1.b: Proximity to Emory University, DeKalb County Schools, and community business center. Street car transportation. Restricted to residential.

2.a: Business men, clerical workers, professors, and students

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Emory University section and northeast portion of Druid Hills (outside city- in DeKalb County)

1.c: Water rate twice that of city. Outside city, hence dependent upon DeKalb County police protection and special arrangement necessary for fire protection.
1.b: Proximity to good schools and Emory University whose students and teachers create housing demand; bus transportation along North Decatur Road, between Decatur and end of Emory carline. Restricted for residential.

2.a: Business and professional men; some clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area, should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Emory Highlands and Emory Estates (All outside city and all in DeKalb County)

C17.name: Southern portion of Emory Highlands and Chelsea Heights (both are outside of city and are in DeKalb County)

1.c: Considerable distance from center of city. Dependent upon DeKalb County police protection.
1.b: Proximity to Emory University, community business centers and schools. Bus transportation along North Decatur Road. Restricted to residential.

2.a: Business men and clerical workers and teachers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held. Southern portion of area (Chelsea Heights) is resurrected subdivision. Now being developed and contains about 5 or 6 new residences built within last two years, two of which still remain unsold. Apparently there is little sales demand for property in this rough, heavily wooded subdivision, through which an open creek runs.

6.1: Southern portion of Emory Highlands and Chelsea Heights (both are outside of city and are in DeKalb County)

D11.name: Oldest portion of Inman Park Fulton Bag and Cotton Mills area

1.c: Age and poor repair condition of properties. Heavy traddic on DeKalb and Edgewood Avenues and on Fair Street. Traversed by belt line A&WP and main line Georgia RR. Proximity to industrial plants, Fulton Bag and Cotton Mill railroad shops and freight yards. Difficulty of rental collections. Lack of paved streets.
1.b: Accessible to schools, small park, community business centers, and churches. Street car transportation on Edgewood and Moreland Avenues, and on Fair Street.

2.a: Clerical workers, skilled mechanics and mill workers

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold as quickly as possible

6.1: Oldest portion of Inman Park, Fulton Bag and Cotton Mills area

1.c: Mixture of racial groups. Difficulty of rental collections. Poor repair condition of properties. Some vandalism. Main line of Georgia RR traverses area. Heavy traffic on DeKalb Avenue. Proximity to industrial plants, including V.C. fertilizer plant.
1.b: Near occupants' source of employment. Street car transportation along Woodbine and DeKalb Avenues. Negro schools and churches in area.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold as quickly as possible

6.1: Edgewood section (in DeKalb County)

C24.name: Glenwood Ave. to Georgia R.R., between Moreland and East Side Avenues (majority in DeKalb County)

1.c: Some of streets unpaved. North portion adversly affected by proximity of main line of Georgia Railroad, industrial property along same, white D grade property in D-11 and negro property in D-10. Heavy traffic along Moreland, Flat Shoals, and Glenwood Avenues and Fair and Hardee Sts.
1.b: Street carline along Moreland Avenue and Arkwright Place, as well as that along DeKalb Avenue, which is accessible to northern portion. Schools, churches, and community business centers.

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Glenwood Ave. to Georgia R R, between Moreland and East Side Avenues (Majority in DeKalb County)

C25.name: Ormwood and Brownwood (eastern portion in DeKalb County)

1.c: Some of streets unpaved. Heavy vehicular traffic along Moreland and Confederate and Glenwood Avenues. Proximity to Confederate Soldiers' Home and belt line of A and W.P. Railroad.
1.b: Street car transportation along Moreland and Underwood Avenues. Schools, churches and community business centers in area.

2.a: Principally clerical workers and some skilled mechanics

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Ormwood and Brownwood (eastern portion in DeKalb County)

C22.name: East Lake (All in DeKalb County, but portion in Atlanta and portion in Decatur)

1.c: Five miles from center of Atlanta. Some streets unpaved. Heavy vehicular traffic along East Lake Drive, Boulevard Drive and Fair Street (Memorial Drive). Cemetery and Scottish Rite Hospital for Crippled Children in area.
1.b: Area served Cottage Grove and Oak View carline. Proximity to East Lake golf course, schools, and community business centers.

2.a: Business and professional men; clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this section should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: East Lake (All in DeKalb County, but portion in Atlanta and portion in Decatur)

B21.name: Portion of East Lake (in City of Atlanta and in DeKalb County)

1.c: Considerable distance from high schools and Atlanta and Decatur business centers.
1.b: Restricted. Proximity to East Lake golf club. Reasonably accessible to schools and community business center. Street car transportation.

2.a: Business and professional men, some clerical workers

j.6: Built for home owners hence, no sales

i.6: Built for home owners hence, no sales

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area, should be held for fair value.

6.1: Portion of East Lake (in City of Atlanta and in DeKalb County)

1.e: Static for negro, Down for white
1.c: Less than 10% of streets paved. Difficulty of rental collections. Poor repair condition of properties. Some mixture of racial groups.
1.b: Street car transportation on Howard Avenue and McDonough Street. Close to occupants' source of employment. Proximity to Decatur business section. Negro schools, churches, and community business center in area.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Negro area in Decatur (DeKalb County)

C20.name: Oakhurst and older portion of Decatur (in DeKalb County and city of Decatur)

1.c: Main line of Georgia Railraod traverses north portion. Age and spotted repair condition of many properties. Some streets unpaved. Heavy vehicular traffic along College Avenue.
1.b: South Decatur carline through area and North Decatur car line along railway in northern portion of area. Proximity to schools, churches, Agness Scott College (girls) and Decatur business section.

2.a: Business and professional men, clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold rather than held. Good demand among Decatur older families for property on South Candler and Adams Streets in this area, even though properties are of considerable age.

6.1: Oakhurst and older portion of Decatur (in DeKalb County and city of Decatur)

B20.name: Comfort Hill (Metz subdivision) and Columbia Drive section (in Decatur and DeKalb County)

1.c: Practically none.
1.b: Schools in area. Proximity to Agnes Scott College (girls) and Columbia Theological Seminary. Restricted. Reasonably accessible to Decatur business center and street car transportation facilities.

2.a: Business and professional men, some clerical workers

i.4: Built for homes, hence, no sales

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area, should be held for fair value.

6.1: Comfort Hill (Mets subdivision) and Columbia Drive section (In Decatur and DeKalb County)

1.c: Poor repair condition of properties. Instability of incomes of area's occupants. Difficulty of rental collections. No paved streets.
1.b: Street car transportation along College Avenue. Proximity to Decatur business section.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Week's subdivision (in Decatur, Dekalb County)

C18.name: Older portion of Clairmont Park, Clairmont Road frontage, and Sycamore Heights (in DeKalb County, city of Decatur)

1.c: Heavy vehicular traffic along Clairmont and Ponce de Leon Avenues and North Church Street (Lawrencebille Highway). Apartment houses in area. Proximity of negro D grade property and business property around Court House Square and along main line of Georgia Railroad.
1.b: Bus transportation along Clairmont and West Ponce de Leon Avenues, with street car transportation along East Ponce de Leon Ave. Majority of area restricted. Good schools and churches in area. Proximity to Decatur business center and Agnes Scott College (girls).

2.a: Executives, business men and clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold. (a) Very few sales in this type of property in last 10 years. Extreme eastern portion contains cheaper type property and occupants than elsewhere in area. Due to the desire of Decatur's older families to live on Sycamore Street, good demand exists for property on same, regardless of age. This same condition also exists to a lesser degree on Clairmont Avenue and South Candler Street in C-20.

6.1: Older portion of Clairmont Park, Clairmont Road frontage, and Sycamore Heights (In DeKalb Bounty, city of Decatur).

B17.name: Clairmont Estates and Ponce de Leon Heights (All in DeKalb County and majority in City of Decatur)

1.c: Practically none.
1.b: Bus line along Clairmont and Ponce de Leon Avenues; Proximity to schools, churches, and Decatur business sections. Restricted.
1.a: Ranges from level sloping open land to well-wooded rolling land.

2.a: Business and professional men; some clerical workers

areaDesc.5: If older property acquired in area, should be sold rather than held for better prices. N-W portion of area, excluding Clairmont Av frontage, is Clairmont Estates subdivision, recently opened, and contains 5 or 6 new houses, half of which have been built for sale some 90 days and have not yet been sold. Grading and installation of utilities is still proceeding. Ponce de Leon Heights subdivision was developed prior to depression, reamining dormant during the depression, and during the past few years has shown considerable new residential construction activity in the western portion. The new Atlanta to Lawrenceville Highway, cutting off Decatur, is now being constructed and skirts the northwest boundary of the area.

6.1: Clairmont Estates and Ponce de Leon Heights (All in DeKalb County and majority in City of Decatur)

B18.name: Clairmont Park (in Decatur and DeKalb County)

1.c: Inadequate transportation facilities.
1.b: Restricted. Reasonably accessible to schools, churches, and Decatur business center.

2.a: Business and professional men, some clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area, should be held for fair value

6.1: Clairmont Park (in Decatur and DeKalb County)

1.c: Lack of paved streets. Distance to negro schools. Proximity of cemetery.
1.b: Close to occupants' source of employment. Street car transportation along East Ponce de Leon Avenue.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold rather than held. This area is occupied by better type negro.

6.1: Hunter subdivision (in Decatur, DeKalb County)

B19.name: Older portion of Glanwood Estates (in Decatur and DeKalb County)

1.c: Practically none.
1.b: Large lots. Restricted, Reasonably accessible to schools, churches, and Decatur business center. Good street car transportation.

2.a: Decatur executives, business and professional men

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area, should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Older portion of Glenwood Estates (In Decatur and DeKalb County)

D5.name: Hill crest and Avondale (in DeKalb County)

1.c: Mixture of racial groups. Heavy vehicular traffic along Covington Road (Covington Highway). Proximity of main line of George R.R. Encroachment of business along Covington Highway. Difficulty of rental collections. Some vandalism. Instability of incomes of area's occupants. Only Covington Road paved.
1.b: Close to occupants' source of employment. Proximity to community business center of Avondale. Street car transportation (10 cents) along Covington Road.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held. Negroes occupy northeast portion

6.1: Hill crest and Avondale (in DeKalb County)

C19.name: Avondale Estates (in DeKalb County - City of Avondale)

1.c: Ten cent street car fare on Stone Mountain car line. Heavy vehicular traffic on Covington Road. Seven miles from center of city. Excessive building restrictions.
1.b: Highly restricted. Good scenic features. Schools, community business centers and recreation centers in area. Proximity to Forrest Hills Country Club and Ingleside Country Club. Subdivision well landscaped.

2.a: Business men and some clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held. This subdivision was developed on an extensive scale prior to the depression, but has witness no new residential construction for the past 9 years. During the depression the owner of the subdivision became financilly involved and at public sale lots sold at 10 to 20% of original sales price and in many instances sold at less than cost of paving assessments against the lots. However, the $7.500 building restrictions are still in force, which has prevented the construction of cheaper type homes. While this area has witnessed drastic shrinkage of values and heavy foreclosures, it is a desirable residential area from many standpoints and it is believed that the subdivision's desirability and values will stabilize at about present levels.

6.1: Avondale Estates (in DeKalb County- City of Avondale)

1.e: Down for white, Static for negroes
1.c: Poor repair condition of many properties. Grand Avenue only paved street. Proximity to cotton mill and main line of Georgia RR. Inadequeate sewage disposal facilities. Most of area considerable distance from school. Difficulty of rental collections. Some vandalism. Heavy vehicular traffic on Grand Avenue.
1.b: Close to occupants' source of employment (Scottdale Mills). Stone Mountain car line (10 cents) traverses area.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Scottsdale Mill section and Ingleside

1.c: Age of majority of properties. Southern portion adjoining Grant Park subject to disagreeable odors from zoo during summer. Proximity to belt line of A and W P Railroad, along which are located monumental stone and other types of industrial plants.
1.b: Proximity to municipal golf course, Grant Park, schools, and community business center. Adequate street car transportation. Proximity to center of city.

2.a: Clerical and factory wrokers; skilled mechanics

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold as quickly as possible

6.1: Grant Park section

D12.name: Capitol Avenue section (oldest residential area in Atlanta)

1.c: Instability of income of majority of occupants. Mixture of racial groups. Heavy juvenile delinquency. High infant mortality and tubercilosis incidences. High concentration of criminal element. Rental collections difficult. Heavy vandalism. Properties antiquated and in poor repair. Low standards of living. Heavy vehicular traffic throughout area.
1.b: Close to center of city. Both negro and white schools, churches, and community business centers in area. Majority of streets paved. Eastern portion accessible to Grant Park and Municipal Gold Course. Adequate street car transportation.

2.a: Skilled mechanics, factory workers and laborers

areaDesc.5: (a) This applies to white property; there is some slight demand for negro property on investment basis. (b) On white property, poor; on negro property, good. This area contains oldest residential property in Atlanta and is known as one of the city's worst slum areas.

6.1: Capitol Avenue section (oldest residential section in Atlanta)

A2.name: Southwestern portion of Peachtree Heights Park, Westover, and Haynes Manor (all outside of city)

1.c: Gas not available to all sections of area; water rate twice city rate. Much of area is considerable distance from Buckhead fire station. Street car service only along Peachtree Road to Buckhead presents difficulty of transporting negro servants. Sewerage settling basin near southern boundary.
1.b: Restricted and recently zoned for one-family residential. Proximity to municipal golf course. Low effective tax rate. Reasonably accessible to schools, churches and community business centers.

areaDesc.5: (a) - Peachtree Battle Avenue, Dellwood Drive, and a portion of Manor Ridge Drive were improved with houses prior to depression, but majority of the houses in the area have been erected since the depression. Restrictions in southern portion of area, along Woodward Way and Dellwood Drive, are lower than in remainder of area. Property if acquired in this area should be held for fair value.

6.1: Southwestern portion of Peachtree Heights Park, Westover, and Haynes Manor (All outside of city)

A1.name: Tuxedo Park, West Paces Ferry Rd. and Peachtree Heights Park (all outside of city)

1.c: Gas not available to all sections of area; water rate twice city rate. Much of area is considerable distance from Buckhead fire station. Street car service only along Peachtree Road to Buckhead presents difficulty of transporting negro servants. Septic tanks in area.
1.b: Majority of area highly restricted. Recently zoned for one-family residences. Reasonably accessible to schools, churches, community business centers. Low effective tax rate.
1.a: Rolling with natural home sites. Well wooded, beautifully lanscaped

i.6: Built for owners hence no sales

b.1: Brick, Br. V, Hollow tile, etc.
b.2: Brick, Br. V, Hollow tile, etc.
b.3: Brick, Br. V, Hollow tile, etc.

areaDesc.5: a-southern portion; b-northern portion. This is community's most exclusive resiential area, in which live some of the city's most wealthy families. Large estates in area. Peachtree Heights Park was developed about 20 years ago and hence contains older properties than in the Tuxedo Park section which is to a certain extent drawing from Peachtree Heights Park. Property if acquired in this area should be held for fair value.

6.1: Tuxedo Park, West Paces Ferry Rd. section and Peachtree Heights Park (all outside of city)

B2.name: Older portion of Peachtree Heights Park (outside of city)

1.c: Heavy vehicular traffic along Peachtree Road. Water rates twice city rate. Encroachment of apartments and business along Peachtree Road. Several large churches on Peachtree Road.
1.b: Street car transportation along Peachtree Road. Recently zoned for one-family residential and majority restricted. Proximity to schools, churches, and community business center. Low effective tax rate.

areaDesc.5: There are two large apartment houses in this area on Peachtree Road, with apartments renting for $50-$75 per mo. Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Older portion of Peachtree Heights Park (outside of city)

C3.name: Peachtree Road section, Peachtree Hills, and southern portion of Peachtree Heights (outside city)

1.c: Water rate twice that of city. Distance from Buckhead fire station. Heavy vehicular traffic along Peachtree Road. Proximity of main line of Seaboard Railroad to southern portion of area. Spotted condition of many properties from standpoint of repair condition and quality of construction.
1.b: Restricted for residential. Proximity to schools and churches. Street car transportation along Peachtree Road.
1.a: Level to rolling; majority sparsely wooded.

2.a: Business and professional men, clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area, should be sold rather than held. Residents in higher income bracket live in apartments along Peachtree Road. One large apartment house was erected about a year ago. A limited dividend housing project (known as Peachtree Hills Apartment) is now under construction immediately east of this area at an approximate cost of $800,000, financed by F H A Title II loan for $640,000, made by New York Life Insurance Company. When completed, the project will house 174 families.

6.1: Peachtree Road section, Peachtree Hills, and southern portion of Peachtree Heights (outside city)

B3.name: Northern portion of Peachtree Terrace and all of Peachtree Heights (outside city)

1.c: Water rate is twice city rate. Age and spotted repair condition of many properties.
1.b: Restricted. Parks and lake. Street car transportation on Peachtree Road. Reasonable accessible to schools, churches, and community business center. Low effective tax rate.

2.a: Business and professional men and some clerical workers.

areaDesc.5: This area contains a mixture of several types of property; some is new and in excellent repair conditions, while some is old and in only fair repair condition. most of new activity has been confined to easter portion of the area. Property if acquired in western portion of area, should be sold; if in easter portion, should be held for fair value.

6.1: Northern portion of Peachtree Terrace and all of Peachtree Heights (outside city)

B1.name: Paces Ferry Road Development Company's property (outside city)

1.c: Proximity to small negro settlement and expansion of Buckhead business center. Jerry-building in area.
1.b: Proximity to high-class residential section, Buckhead business center, schools, churches, and street car transportation. Restricted. Low effective tax rate.

2.a: Executive, business and professional and clerical workers

areaDesc.5: This area contains mixture of one and two-story residences (majority built about 10 yrs ago), while present new construction in area is of speculative two-story type. Little possibility that this area will witness much higher values; hence, property if acquired in this area, should be sold. Southern portion of this area is rear portion of, estates fronting on Peachtree Road.

6.1: Paces Ferry Road Development Company's property (outside city)

1.c: Absence of zoning. Heavy traffic along Peachtree Road. Encroachment of apartments and commercial properties. Negroo D grade area surrounded by eastern portion of this area. Water rate twice that of city.
1.b: Street car transportation on Peachtree Road. Proximity to schools, churches, and Buckhead business center.
1.a: Mostly level with some rolling and wooded.

2.a: Mixture: business and professional men, clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Area contains several large apartment houses as well as large churches and business property intermingled along Peachtree Road frontage. The apartments have good rental demand since occupants escape city taxation. The wide range in family incomes is due to presence of a few well-to-do families who still occupy homes in the area, plus the tenants in the apartments who earn good salaries, ranging downward to lower income groups along Peachtree Avenue, Woodland Street and Lookout Place. From home-ownership standpoint, property, if acquired in this area, should be sold; however, in cases where zoning and restrictions permit, it might be better to hold for higher values occasioned by use of property for business purposes.

6.1: Buckhead Section (outside city)

B4.name: Older portion of Garden Hills (outside city)

1.c: Water rate is twice city rate. Septic tanks in area.
1.b: Restricted. Low effective tax rate. Recreation park and swimming pool in area. Proximity to schools, churches, and community business center.

areaDesc.5: Property, if acquired in this area, should be sold rather than held.

6.1: Older portion of Garden Hills (outside city)

A3.name: Newer portion of Garden Hills (outside of city)

1.b: Proximity to schools, churches, community business center, sub-division swimming pool and park. Well restricted. Low effective tax rate.
1.a: Rolling with natural home sites. Well wooded and nicely landscaped.
1.c: Water rate twice city rate. Proximity of northern portion of area to negro area D-1. Street car transportation only along Peachtree Road presents some difficulty of transportation of negro servants.

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be held for fair value.

6.1: Newer portion of Garden Hills (outside of city)

B5.name: Peachtree Highlands and Piedmont Road section (outside city)

1.c: Water rate is twice city rate. Heavy vehicular traffic along Piedmont and Peachtree roads.
1.b: Low effective tax rate. Street car transportation on Peachtree Road. Majority of area restricted. Accessible to schools and community business centers.

2.a: Business and professional men, some clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Most of this area was developed prior to depression, but during the past two or three years the area has shown considerable new construction activity. Property, if acquired in this section, should be held for fair value.

6.1: Peachtree Highlands and Piedmont Road section (outside city)

1.c: Water rate is twice that of city rate. Proximity to main line of Southern R.R.
1.b: Restricted. Proximity to schools and community business center at Buckhead. Low effective tax rate. Street car transportation on Peachtree Road.
1.a: Mostly level with slight rollin eastern portion. Well wooded.

2.a: Smaller business men and some clerical workers

areaDesc.5: (a) This is new subdivision containing about 120 lots (40 of which has been sold) on which have been erected about 20 houses for sale. About 8 of the 20 are under construction or are completed but are held vacant for sale. Considerable speculative building activity in this area. Property if acquired in this area should be held for fair value.

6.1: Peachtree Park (outside of city)

1.c: Water rate is twice city rate. Eastern portion of area is considerable distance from Buckhead fire station. Heavy vehicular traffic along Peachtree Road. Encroachment of business and apartments along Peachtree Road.
1.b: Majority restricted. Low effective tax rate. Street car transportation along Peachtree Road.

2.a: Executives, Business and professional men; office workers.

areaDesc.5: This area contains a mixture of expensive property along Peachtree Road and considerable cheaper property between Lennox and Roxboro Roads (south of Peachtree Road). Property, if acquired in this section, should be held for fair value.

6.1: Peachtree Rd.-Roxboro Rd. section (outside city)

A6.name: Known as H. L. DeFoor Property

1.c: Water rate is twice city rate. Considerable distances from fire station at Buckhead, schools, churches, center of city, and community business center, although these last four factors are not important to the type of resident  occupying this area.
1.b: Proximity to Brookhaven golf club. Restricted. Low effective tax rate. Street car transportation on Peachtree Road for servants.
1.a: Rolling, well wooded land with natural home sites.

areaDesc.5: This area was developed prior to the depression as a high-class residential section, but most of the houses in the area have been erected since the depression. Property, if acquired in this area, should be held for fair value.

6.1: Brookhaven Estates and Country Club Estates (outside city-majority in Fulton County, with small portion in Dekalb County)

1.c: Water rate twice city rate. Considerable distance from fire station at Buckhead and although located at considerable distance from center of city, this factor is not particularly detrimental to type resident in this area.
1.b: Restricted. near Brookhaven Golf Club. Low effective tax rate. Street car transportation on Peachtree Road.

2.a: Smaller business men and some clerical workers

areaDesc.5: This subdivision has been largely developed since depression and contains about 40 houses. Property, if acquired in this area, should be held for fair value.

6.1: Ridgedale Park (outside city)

A7.name: Brookhaven Estates and Country Club Estates (outside city - majority in Fulton County, with small postion in DeKalb County)

1.c: Water rate is twice city rate. Considerable distance from fire station at Buckhead, schools, churches, center of city, and community business center, although these last four factors are not important to the type of resident occupying this area.
1.b: Proximity to Brookhaven golf club. Restricted. Low effective tax rate. Street car transportation on Peachtree Road for servants,
1.a: Rolling, well wooded land with natural home sites.

areaDesc.5: This area was developed prior to the depression as a high-class residential section, but most of the houses in the area have been erected since the depression. Property, if acquired in this area, should be held for fair value.

6.1: Brookhaven Estates and Country Club Estates (outside city majority in Fulton County, with small portion in Dekalb county)

C2.name: Brookhaven and Brookhaven Heights (outside city and in DeKalb County)

1.c: Only small percentage of streets in area paved. Absence of zoning. Water rate twice that of city. Considerable distance from Buckhead fire station. Dependent upon DeKalb County police protection. Proximity to main line of Seaboard Railroad. Cheap type of construction with some jerry-building.
1.b: Proximity to schools. Street car transportation along Peachtree Road. Restricted to residential.

2.a: Clerical workers, skilled mechanics, truck farmers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold as quicly as possible.

6.1: Brookhaven and Brookhaven Heights (outside city and in DeKalb County)

B7.name: Wieuca Road portion and Northridge Park (outside city)

1.c: Considerable distance from Buckhead fire station, schools, churches, community business centers, center of city, and transportation.
1.b: Majority of area restricted. Low effective tax rate.

areaDesc.5: This area was dormant during depression but during past two years has shown considerable new residential construction activity. Property, if acquired in this area, should be held for fair value.

6.1: Wieuca Road portion and Northridge Park (outside city)

D27.name: Older portion of Jefferson Park, East Point

1.c: Age and poor repair condition of many properties. Proximity to two main line railroads and industrial pllants in East Point, including fertilizer plant. Portion of area considerable distance from street car transportation. Proximity to Municipal Airport.
1.b: Proximity to schools, churches, East Point business center, and occupants' source of employment.

areaDesc.5: Property in this area, if acquired, should be sold, rather than held.

6.1: Older portion of Jefferson Park, East Point.

B16.name: Druid Hills (Majority outside city - all of area in DeKalb County)

1.e: slightly upward in NE portion; remainder static.
1.c: Eastern portion a considerable distance from schools, churches, and community business centers.
1.b: Western portion adjoings Candler Park and has street car transportation; zoned for residentail and restricted.
1.a: All well wooded; western portion level and eastern portion rolling.

2.a: Executives, business and professional men; some clerical workers

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be held for fair value. Massell Subdivision portion of this area has shown considerable activity in past 5 years and might possibly be graded "low green."

6.1: Massell Subdivision and property adjoining east side of Candler Park (all in DeKalb County)

C11.name: Ponce de Leon Avenue to Edgewood Ave. between Moreland Ave. and Southern Railroad belt line (includes Linwood, Copenhill, and Inman Park)

1.c: Proximity of commercial properties located along Southern Railroad belt line. Heavy traffic along Virginia Avenue. Proximity to baseball park. Presence of apartments in southern portions of area.
1.b: Proximity to park, crecreation center, school, and community business center. Street car transportation on Boulevard.

areaDesc.5: Property if acquired in this area should be sold rather than held

6.1: Older portion of North Boulevard Park to Ponce de Leon Avenue
